intro: Abarema hendersonii, commonly known as the Henderson's acacia, is a flowering plant native to Brazil. It belongs to the Fabaceae family, which is characterized by its legume fruits and nitrogen-fixing abilities. The plant features bipinnate leaves and produces yellow flowers arranged in racemose inflorescences. It is typically found in tropical and subtropical regions, thriving in well-drained soils. Due to its ornamental value, it is occasionally cultivated in botanical gardens and as a decorative plant.
distribution_native_art_desc: Abarema hendersonii is primarily native to the Atlantic Forest region of eastern Brazil. This species is found in the states of Espírito Santo, Minas Gerais, and Rio de Janeiro. It typically grows in humid, tropical environments with well-drained soils. The plant is often associated with secondary vegetation and disturbed areas within this biome. Due to habitat loss, it is considered a rare and endangered species in its native range.
